vectorData.altText:
Hairs are keratinized filaments produced by follicles. They are distributed everywhere, except palms of hands and soles of feet (thick skin), the lips, and around the openings of the urogenital system.
Follicles include both epithelial and CT components; are associated with sebaceous glands and smooth muscle structures, the arrector pili. 
Sebaceous glands produce sebum, which lubricates hair and skin; usually open into a hair follicle.
Arrector pili muscle contraction 1) fxns in thermoregulation: it causes hair to stand on end, as occurs when one is cold, thereby trapping  warm air closer to the body; 2) compresses the sebaceous gland, and thereby promotes the secretion of sebum
Follicular bulge: a niche of epidermal stem cells at the level of arrector pili attachment that normally sustains the growth of hair and sebaceous glands
Hair bulb is the expanded base of the follicle; contains the germinative cells, the hair matrix, which gives rise to the hair and its inner covering
Melanocytes within matrix supply keratinocytes with melanin; type and density determines hair colour
Dermal papilla: a highly vascularized peg of loose CT that nourishes the avascular matrix
That's right!  Arrector pilli is a smooth muscle that fxns in thermoregulation and promotes sebaceous gland secretion upon contraction.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
